;;救援人员在墨西哥塔毛利帕斯州马德罗城教堂屋顶倒塌后搜寻被困人员。
;

;当局称，墨西哥北部一座教堂的屋顶在周日弥撒期间倒塌，造成至少 9 人死亡、约 50 人受伤，搜救人员深夜在废墟中搜寻幸存者和其他受害者。

;

;官员称，屋顶塌陷时，据信约有 30 名教区居民被困在废墟中。搜索人员在屋顶板下爬行，官员们还带了狗来帮助寻找可能的幸存者。

;

;塔毛利帕斯州警方表示，倒塌时教堂内约有 100 人。

;

; >;国家安全发言人办公室周日晚间表示，已确认有 9 人因倒塌事故死亡，并称此次倒塌可能是由“结构性故障”造成的。

;

;塔毛利帕斯州警方表示，国民警卫队部队已出动、州警察、州民防办公室和红十字会参与了这次行动。

;

;墨西哥主教委员会发表声明说：“我们为悲惨的生命损失和受伤人员一起祈祷.”

; ;

;墙壁似乎没有被向外炸开，也没有任何爆炸迹象，也没有任何其他结构性破坏的迹象。

;

;国家当局分发的照片显示了教堂某些部分长凳顶部的屋顶板。这使得有可能为任何幸存者提供空气空间。

;

;“目前，正在开展必要的工作，以营救仍在废墟下的人们，”阿尔瓦雷斯在录音中说道。 “今天我们正在经历一个非常困难的时刻。”

;

;国家民防办公室发布的视频显示，屋顶的外缘由短木块支撑。

;

;展示了最初的努力，用起重机将教堂中央靠近地面的倒塌屋顶的部分吊起。但该办公室表示，由于现在正在摇摇欲坠的一块楼板可能会倒塌并危及幸存者，因此放弃了抬起屋顶部分的努力。

;

;该视频描述了官员如何恢复手动救援。显然，救援人员用木支柱或液压千斤顶派到了石板下面，以帮助被困在下面的人。经过专门训练的狗也被派往废墟中寻找幸存者。

;

;民防办公室表示，这些狗最初似乎并没有发现幸存者的迹象，因此采用了过去地震中使用过的旧方法：派遣救援队进入废墟中大声喊叫并聆听任何反应的迹象。

;

;国家地震局没有报告任何强度足以在倒塌时造成此类损害的地震活动。也没有立即发生爆炸的迹象。

; Mon, 02 Oct 2023 12:52:01 +0800 Rescuers continue search for bodies at Spanish nightclubs after deadly blazehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/02/la-fonda-club-fire-murcia-spain-injuries-death-count-missing-teatre-golden-clubs

;;西班牙穆尔西亚三个相邻夜总会发生火灾后失踪人员的朋友和家人。
;

;西班牙三个相邻夜总会发生的火灾造成的死亡人数预计还会上升，救援人员正在废墟中搜寻另外五人，火灾发生后据报失踪。;造成至少13人死亡;。

;

;南部大火-官员称，周日早上 6 点左右，东部城镇穆尔西亚的 La Fonda 俱乐部爆发了火灾，然后蔓延到邻近的 Teatre 和 Golden 俱乐部。

;

;关于下落不明人数的报道各不相同。当地报纸，;La Verdad de Mercia; 援引该镇市长 José Ballesta 的话说，据报道有 18 人失踪。该数字可能包括一些已经发现的火灾。

;

;起火原因正在调查中。

; ;

;截至周日晚些时候，仅通过指纹确认了三具尸体的身份。官员们表示，剩余尸体的身份识别可能需要数天时间，因为 DNA 样本必须送往马德里进行处理。

;

;失踪者中有一对夫妇，Jorge 和 Rosa Bajiota，他们是从据《世界报》报道，他和两个朋友在附近的卡拉瓦卡镇（Caravaca）工作。这对夫妇育有三个孩子。

;
;

;;相关：;;西班牙夜总会发生火灾，至少 13 人死亡;

;
;

;当晚陪同他们前往夜总会的一位朋友向她的母亲在火灾中说道：“妈妈，我爱你。我们会死的，妈妈，我爱你。”在背景中，可以听到人们大声喊叫，要求开灯。

;

;目前尚不清楚死者中是否有这名 28 岁的女子，但只有西班牙媒体确认了她的父亲的身份。 Jairo 表示，他没有收到她的任何进一步消息。

;

;Ballesta 表示，建筑物的结构损坏使得进入变得非常困难。

; ;

;“我们现在正在做的就是努力提取尸体、保护该地区、照顾家人、辨认他们的身份，这根本不容易，” Ballesta 说。

;

;官员称，有四人因吸入烟雾而接受治疗，其中两名年龄分别为 22 岁和 25 岁的女性和两名 40 岁左右的男性。

;

;“根据初步信息，国家警察发言人迭戈·塞拉尔 (Diego Seral) 告诉穆尔西亚翁达地区广播电台 (Radio Onda Regional de Murcia)，夜总会一楼发生火灾，该夜总会分为一楼和一楼。

;

;到目前为止，共有 13 具尸体，其中有 11 具。在拉方达一楼发现了被发现的物品，在底层的废墟中发现了两件。据 La Verdad de Mercia 报道，警方称夜总会内的温度可能达到 1,000 至 1,500 摄氏度。

;

;失踪者之一是埃里克·埃尔南德斯 (Éric Hernández)，他来自尼加拉瓜，当时正在庆祝自己的 30 岁生日据该报报道，他与朋友和家人一起在拉方达，包括他的兄弟塞尔吉奥和母亲玛塔。据称，该党有八名成员失踪。

;

;该市宣布为死者哀悼三天，穆尔西亚市政厅外下半旗致哀。

;

;西班牙金表示，在“穆尔西亚这一悲惨的一天”之后，他感到“痛苦和沮丧”，并感谢救援人员所做的“模范工作”。

;

;总理佩德罗·桑切斯表示“对遇难者和亲属表示声援”穆尔西亚一家夜总会发生悲惨火灾”。

; Mon, 02 Oct 2023 12:22:02 +0800 Paris-Berlin relations slump is holding up key EU decisions, says German MEPhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/02/paris-berlin-relations-slump-is-holding-up-key-eu-decisions-says-german-mep
;;2023-10-02T04:00:03Z;
;
;;Olaf Scholz 观看埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 9 月份在新德里举行的 G20 领导人峰会上就座。
;

;一位有影响力的德国欧洲议会议员声称，法国和德国之间的不良关系正在减缓欧盟的关键决策，包括乌克兰国防和贸易协议。

;

;欧洲议会外交事务主席戴维·麦卡利斯特 (David McAllister)事务委员会和反对派基督教民主党的关键人物表示，他担心德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨和法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙之间缺乏接触，导致有关主战坦克和战斗机的关键决策被推迟。以及未来与拉丁美洲的贸易协议。

;

;“目前，我们发现巴黎和柏林之间明显缺乏内部协调。这不好，”麦卡利斯特说。

;

;他说，长期以来被认为是欧盟驱动力的法德关系并不是“欧洲的一切”，而是两国之间如果没有合作“事情行不通”。

;

;“最终，巴黎和柏林需要达成一致才能顺利解决问题……这就是我批评德国政府的地方。我不认为巴黎和柏林之间的合作如此之少，正如我们目前所看到的那样。”他补充道。

;

;德国总理的前任安格拉·默克尔 (Angela Merkel) 在 16 年间建立了密切的关系。与包括马克龙在内的四位法国总统共事多年，为她赢得了欧盟事实上的领导人的认可。专家们一致认为，欧盟现在正在失去这种牢固的工作关系。

;

;麦卡利斯特说，最“突出的例子”之一是就下一代欧洲主战坦克做出决定的斗争，这是一个不可分割的整体乌克兰或任何其他未来战区主要作战系统的一部分。

;

;上个月，法国武装部队部长塞巴斯蒂安·勒科尔努 (Sébastien Lecornu) 会面后，巴黎和柏林承诺在今年年底前取得进展。和他的德国同行鲍里斯·皮斯托利斯（Boris Pistorius），但一些人认为需要更多的政治动力来加快决策速度。

;

;由默克尔领导的麦卡利斯特的中右翼政党在过去两年里一直反对”麦卡利斯特在国防部长会晤前接受采访时表示：“我们再次没有推进欧洲主战坦克的开发。”

;

;但他表示，这只是弱点的一个例子

;

;“我们没有看到下一代飞机有任何进展，”他说。他说，与拉丁美洲国家的南方共同市场集团的贸易协议也没有取得进展。

;

;麦卡利斯特引用了德国领导人 8 月份在布拉格发表的讲话，反映出双方内心缺乏联系。

;

;“你能想象吗：他就欧洲的未来——尤其是国防和安全——谈了 45 分钟，却没有提到法国？我的意思是，如果不与法国合作，您将与谁一起组织欧洲防务和安全？法国是欧洲领先的军事力量，英国人离开了我们，”麦卡利斯特说。

;

;法国也有同样的观点。巴黎蒙田研究所欧洲项目主任乔治娜·赖特 (Georgina Wright) 表示：“我的观点是，是的，两国关系很紧张。是的，根据实际的政策分歧和方法，他们需要克服一些关键问题。但我们不应该过分夸大其词。

;

;“我们正处于一个不信任的时期……但就敌意而言，这与 2017 年和 2018 年英国和法国之间发生的情况相去甚远。与此同时，你必须记住，法德关系比法英关系重要得多，”她说。

;

;“我认为巴黎有一种观点，即德国只是花钱太多时间自言自语。所以你已经形成了一个联盟……三个非常不同的政党，他们只是花了太多时间在[国内]商定一项新政策，以至于当政策到达布鲁塞尔时，他们还没有时间与其他地方讨论它。事实上，我不仅从法国那里听到了这一点，而且还从其他成员国那里听到了这一点，”赖特补充道。

;

;“我们不应该忽视这一事实，尽管他们存在根本分歧，以及不同的做法，这两个政府不仅每周多次讲话，而且涉及所有部委和各级，”赖特补充道。

;

;本周，柏林和罗马之间关系的断层也暴露出来，乔治亚·梅洛尼 (Giorgia Meloni) 写信抗议德国计划资助两个在意大利开展业务的移民非政府组织。

;

;这可能导致意大利决定拒绝与 ;上周在布鲁塞尔举行的内政部长峰会上提出了关于欧盟移民法改革的新文本;。

; Mon, 02 Oct 2023 12:22:02 +0800 Tom Hanks says AI version of him used in dental plan ad without his consenthttps://www.theguardian.com/film/2023/oct/02/tom-hanks-dental-ad-ai-version-fake
;;2023-10-02T01:17:24Z;
;
;;演员汤姆·汉克斯
;

;汤姆·汉克斯警告粉丝，出现一则牙科计划广告使用他的图像实际上是假的，并且是使用人工智能创建的。

;

;在向他的 950 万 Instagram 粉丝发布的消息中，这位演员表示，他的图像在未经他许可的情况下被使用。 “谨防！！有一个视频用我的人工智能版本宣传一些牙科计划。我与此无关。”;汉克斯在截图中写道剪辑中计算机生成的自己的图像;。

;

;这位奥斯卡奖得主过去曾对人工智能在电影和电视中的使用表示担忧，尽管他并不回避批准数字化在电影中修改了自己的版本。

;

;2004 年的电脑动画圣诞幻想片《极地快车》以 CGI 版本的汉克斯为主角。他还在 2022 年电影 ;一个叫奥托的男人。;

;
;

;;相关：;;好莱坞作家如何战胜人工智能——以及它为何重要;

;
;

;与英国喜剧演员亚当·巴克斯顿交谈;4 月 18 日，就在好莱坞编剧罢工开始前几天，汉克斯在他的播客中谈到人工智能：“我们预见到了这一点。我们看到，将有能力在计算机中取零和一，并将其​​转换为面孔和角色。现在，从那时起，这个数字只增长了十亿倍，而且我们随处可见。

;

;“我可以告诉你，所有的行会、所有的机构、所有的组织都在进行讨论。律师事务所提出我的脸和我的声音（以及其他人的）作为我们的知识产权的法律后果。

;

;“现在，如果我愿意，我可以聚在一起提出一系列七部由我主演的电影，从现在开始，直到天国来临，我将年满 32 岁。现在，任何人都可以通过人工智能或深度造假技术在任何年龄重新创造自己。”

;

;汉克斯告诉巴克斯顿，人工智能可以让他的假版本永远继续表演。

;

; >;“明天我可能会被公共汽车撞到，仅此而已，但表演可以继续下去。除了了解这是通过人工智能或深度伪造完成的之外，没有任何东西可以告诉你这不是我一个人的。而且它将具有一定程度的逼真品质。这当然是一种艺术挑战，但也是一种法律挑战。”

;
;

;;相关：;;“我们正在经历一场大革命”：人工智能如何让银幕上的明星抗衰老;

;
;

;美国作家罢工于上周结束，主要症结之一是;担心不受控制的人工智能可能会破坏创意工作。;美国编剧协会批准了与电影联盟的一项协议，并且;电视;对人工智能在电影和电视中的使用方式进行了限制。

;

;但是 Sag-Aftra –代表好莱坞演员的工会仍在罢工，这意味着大多数制作无法恢复。 ;演员罢工;编剧罢工几个月后，争议的核心问题就开始了，薪资问题以及对使用人工智能生成未经批准的演员肖像的担忧。人们希望编剧的协议能够帮助解决好莱坞演员的罢工问题。

;

;在罗伯特·泽米吉斯执导的电影《这里》中，将于明年上映，汤姆·汉克斯将;使用形而上学的工具扮演年轻版本的角色。; 这家人工智能公司表示，它可以在演员现场实时表演的基础上创建“高分辨率、逼真的换脸和去衰老效果，而无需进一步的合成或视觉特效工作”。

; Mon, 02 Oct 2023 10:22:01 +0800 Biden urges Republicans to approve Ukraine aid, saying support cannot waverhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/02/joe-biden-republicans-ukraine-aid-plan-volodymyr-zelenskiy
;;2023-10-02T01:04:41Z;
;
;;周日，在乌克兰利沃夫的 Lychakiv 公墓，一名仪仗队在乌克兰捍卫者纪念仪式上行进。乔·拜登敦促国会共和党人通过一项单独的乌克兰援助法案。
;

;乔·拜登敦促国会共和党人支持一项向乌克兰提供更多援助的协议，此前针对基辅的条款被排除在法案之外以避免避免。美国政府关闭。

;

;美国总统周日表示，他对政治边缘政策“感到厌倦”，并且“在任何情况下”都不能中断美国对乌克兰的支持。他说，共和党人已承诺通过单独投票向乌克兰提供援助。

;

;乌克兰总统泽连斯基周日表示，没有直接提及美国的法案，任何事情都不会削弱该国对俄罗斯的打击，而且也不会人们可以“关闭”乌克兰的稳定性、耐力、力量和勇气，这与经常用来指代俄罗斯袭击造成的停电的乌克兰动词相呼应。乌克兰总统在捍卫者日假期发布的录音讲话中发表了上述言论。

;
;

;;相关：;;“能源战争”：乌克兰试图在冬季之前保护电力供应;

;
;

;拜登早些时候对记者表示：“我们在任何情况下都不能允许美国对乌克兰的支持被中断。我完全希望议长信守承诺，确保获得帮助乌克兰所需的通行和支持，帮助他们抵御侵略和残暴。”

;

; Mon, 02 Oct 2023 09:22:01 +0800 Asian Games official in stable condition after being hit by stray hammer throwhttps://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/oct/02/asian-games-2023-official-hit-by-hammer-throw-broken-leg-stable-condition
;;2023-10-01T23:57:27Z;
;
;;Asian Games official Huang Qinhua is stretchered to get medical attention after he was hit in the leg by a hammer in Hangzhou, China.
;

;An athletics official suffered a broken leg and serious bleeding after being hit by a misthrown hammer in the Asian Games in Hangzhou, but his vital signs are now stable.

;

;On Saturday, Kuwait's Ali Zankawi lined up for one of his throws in the men's hammer final at the eastern Chinese city's packed Olympic stadium. But instead of soaring straight onto the outfield, the hammer flew out sideways and low to the right, smashing into the leg of the sitting technical official.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Lee Kang-in targets a prize greater than glory in the Asian Games;

;
;

;Looking horrified, Zankawi sprinted over as blood began spurting from the official's right leg. The official, Huang Qinhua, 62, grimaced and swayed dizzily as Zankawi rushed to check on him, blood shooting out of the wound.

;

;Within seconds Zankawi was using his huge hands and strength to improvise a tourniquet on Huang's thigh and halt the bleeding. Medical personnel soon took Huang away on a stretcher after applying a tourniquet, then sent him to a nearby hospital.

;

;“He arrived at the hospital at 20:15, where was diagnosed with a right open tibiofibular fracture,” Games spokesman Xu Deqing told a news conference on Sunday. “Currently his vital signs are stable.”

; ;

;Afterwards Zankawi looked shaken and was seen asking after the official, according to a Reuters witness.

;

;The final was won by China's Wang Qi. Zankawi finished eighth but still managed a season's best of 67.57 m, which he threw in the second round before his misthrow.

;

;As is common in athletics competitions, the official had sat several metres from the cage-like netting that surrounds the throwing circle where the athletes spin and take their throws.

;

;But the power and velocity of the 7.26kg flying metal ball meant the netting could only slightly cushion the hammer's flight, not stop it.

;

;The netting in athletics is designed to hang relatively loosely to prevent hammer balls and discuses from bouncing back at the athletes after misthrows.

;

;Many users of Chinese social media platform Weibo, where the incident was trending on Sunday, said safety protocols should be improved to offer better protection for officials.

;

;Simmering hostility between Republicans over the ;bipartisan deal; that averted a government shutdown descended into open political warfare on Sunday, a rightwing congressman saying he would move to oust Kevin McCarthy and the ;embattled House speaker; insisting he would survive.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'This is good news': Biden signs stopgap funding bill to avert US shutdown;

;
;

;“We need to rip off the Bandaid. We need to move on with new leadership that can be trustworthy,” the Florida representative Matt Gaetz told CNN's State of the Union, saying he would file a “motion to vacate” in the next few days.

;

;McCarthy, Gaetz said, lied about “a secret deal” struck with Democrats to later pass money for Ukraine that was left out of the compromise agreement, and misled Republicans about working with the opposition at all.

;

;The bill keeping the government funded for 47 days passed the House on Saturday night 335-91, 209 Democrats joining 126 Republicans in support. It cleared the Senate 88-9 and was signed by Joe Biden.

;

;In remarks at the White House on Sunday, Biden said the measure extending funding until 17 November, and including $16bn in disaster aid, prevented “a needless crisis”.

;But, Biden said: “The truth is we shouldn't be here in the first place. It's time to end governing by crisis and keep your word when you give it in the Congress. I fully expect the speaker to keep his commitment to secure the passage of support needed to help Ukraine as they defend themselves against aggression.”

;

;Asked if he expected McCarthy to stand up to extremists, Biden replied: “I hope this experience for the speaker has been one of personal revelation.”

;

;McCarthy hit back at Gaetz, branding him a showman “more interested in securing TV interviews” than keeping government functioning.

;

;“I'll survive,” McCarthy told CBS's Face the Nation. “You know, this is personal with Matt. He wanted to push us into a shutdown, even threatening his own district with all the military people there who would not be paid.

;

;“… So be it.来吧。 Let's get it over with it, and let's start governing. If he's upset because he tried to push us into shutdown and I made sure the government didn't shut down, then let's have that fight.”

;Gaetz said he would no longer hold to an agreement made in January to support McCarthy in exchange for concessions including a hard position on federal funding. ;

;“The only way Kevin McCarthy is speaker of the House at the end of this coming week is if Democrats bail him out, and they probably will,” said Gaetz.

;

;“I'm done owning Kevin McCarthy. We made a deal in January to allow him to assume the speakership and I'm not owning him any more because he doesn't tell the truth. And so if Democrats want to own Kevin McCarthy by bailing him out I can't stop them. But then he'll be their speaker, not mine.”

;

;McCarthy would need 218 votes to keep his job. Some senior Democrats said they would not vote to save him and would back the minority leader, Hakeem Jeffries, instead.

;“Kevin McCarthy is very weak speaker,” Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York told CNN, saying she would support Gaetz's motion.

;

;McCarthy “has clearly has lost control of his caucus. He has brought the US and millions of Americans to the brink, waiting until the final hour to keep the government open and even then only issuing a 4[7]-day extension. We're going to be right back in this place in November.”

;

;Speaking to reporters on Saturday, Jeffries said the deal represented a “total surrender by rightwing extremists”.

;

;Republicans loyal to McCarthy also attacked Gaetz and the rightwing House Freedom Caucus for their “destructive” pledge to oust the speaker.

;

;“What I just heard was a diatribe of delusional thinking,” Mike Lawler of New York told ABC's This Week. “They are the reason we had to work together with House Democrats. That is not the fault of Kevin McCarthy, that's the fault of Matt Gaetz. He's mealy mouthed and, frankly, duplicitous.”

;

;Relations between the speaker and Gaetz reached a new low with a ;testy confrontation; in a meeting on Thursday. Gaetz accused McCarthy of orchestrating a social media campaign against him, the speaker saying he did not rate the congressman highly enough to do so.

;

;On Sunday, Gaetz insisted “this is about keeping Kevin McCarthy to his word, it's not about any personal animosity”.

;

;Gaetz claimed McCarthy reached a “secret deal”, promising to introduce a standalone bill to continue funding Ukraine's efforts to repel Russian invaders.

;

;A growing number of Republicans object to the US helping pay for the war. Gaetz said: “However you think about [Ukraine funding], it should be subject to open review [and] analysis, and not backroom deals, so I have to file a motion to vacate against speaker McCarthy this week.”

;

;On ABC, Gaetz said he did not expect to have enough votes to remove McCarthy immediately, “but I might have them before the 15th ballot”, an allusion to the time it took to elect the speaker in January.

;

;“I am relentless, and I will continue to pursue this objective,” Gaetz said. “And if all the American people see is that it is a uni-party that governs them, always the Biden, McCarthy, Jeffries government that makes dispositive decisions on spending, then I am seeding the fields of future primary contests to get better Republicans in Washington.”

;

;Shalanda Young, Biden's budget director, blamed Republicans for bringing the government to the verge of a shutdown, and urged Congress to take a longer-term view.

;

;“We need to start today to make sure that we do not have this brinkmanship, last-minute anxiousness of the American people,” she told ABC. “Let's do our jobs to not have this happen again. Let's have full-year funding bills at the end of these 47 days.”

;

;The actor Jake Abraham, best known for his role in Guy Ritchie's Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, has died aged 56.

;

;Abraham, who played Dean in the British gangster film, revealed his prostate cancer diagnosis in July and said he was receiving palliative care.

;

;The Liverpool-born actor's other roles included the 1991 Channel 4 series GBH, and the films Mean Machine and Formula 51.

;

;Bill Elms, a Liverpool theatre director and producer who worked with Jake on several occasions, told the Liverpool Echo: “I had the great pleasure of working with Jake on a few shows I co-produced, Twopence to Cross the Mersey and Lennon's Banjo, he was a wonderful actor, a great company member and was much loved by so many in the industry.

;

;“He will be sadly missed. I have many fond memories of Jake, he was always so upbeat and fun to be around. I admired him for going public with his illness, it will make a difference to many others and save lives.

;

;“It's a very sad day. RIP and sending my love to his friends and family.”

;

;Abraham previously told the Echo that he had received his cancer diagnosis after going to the doctors after a long period of illness. The cancer later spread to the rest of his body and tumours developed in his spine, hips and bladder.

;

;“I was working but I wasn't feeling well. I was pushing through those spells when you don't feel yourself, you haven't got the energy and there are aches and pains,” he said.

;

;“What made me go to the doctor and get a PSA (prostate-specific antigen) test was that I passed blood in my urine.

;

;“I got a test and ended up in the Royal. He said: 'You've got cancer, I'm so, so sorry.' He said that I'd had it for years, maybe four years.”

;

;Abraham's character in Ritchie's 1998 classic was one of two incompetent thieves who are sent to steal a pair of antique shotguns.

; Mon, 02 Oct 2023 06:52:01 +0800 Little sign of Tory unity as factions jostle on first day of conferencehttps://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/oct/01/little-sign-of-tory-unity-as-factions-jostle-on-first-day-of-conference
;;2023-10-01T21:30:19Z;
;
;;Rishi Sunak points to both sides of his audience while delivering a speech at the Conservative party conference in Manchester
;

;Rishi Sunak is struggling to hold together his fractured party as the first day of the Conservative conference saw attempts at a united front collapse into rival groups battling over tax, culture wars and the fight to be the next Tory leader.

;

;In his own carefully planned comments, the prime minister used interviews and a rally in Manchester to portray himself as a figure of change, making difficult but necessary long-term choices above the fray of petty politics.

;

;With the event already at risk of being overshadowed by Sunak's continued refusal to say whether HS2 will extend to the city, away from the main conference stage a variety of noisy Tory factions jostled to have their say.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Vultures circle around Sunak as dead-eyed delegates look on | John Crace;

;
;

;In perhaps the most damning comment of the day, Ben Houchen, the Tees Valley mayor and long viewed as a Tory rising star, said he would not bet on his party winning the next election.

;

;“Not at the moment,” he said at a fringe event, adding that Sunak needed to “do more to give people the excuse” to vote Conservative.

;

;Sunak was also coming under increasing pressure to commit to reduce tax before the election, something No 10 wants to do, but approaches with extreme caution given the fiscal repercussions of Liz Truss's unfunded tax cuts.

;

;After more than 30 largely Truss-sympathetic Conservative MPs signed a highly unusual and borderline rebellious pledge that they will not vote for an autumn statement that raises taxes, Michael Gove, the levelling up secretary, called for cuts to personal taxes.

;

;“I would like to see the tax burden reduced before the next election,” Gove told Sky's Sunday with Trevor Phillips programme, highlighting the extent to which even cabinet ministers are freelancing on policy issues – although he later backtracked slightly, telling GB News that inflation needed to fall first.

;

;As pressure mounts on Sunak to make pre-election tax cuts, the chancellor Jeremy Hunt is to announce plans for tougher benefit restrictions on those who “won't even look for work”.

;

;The chancellor will pledge new changes to the benefit sanction system in his speech on Monday, as the government attempts to make savings on its welfare bill. He will also announce a move to an £11 an hour living wage.

;

;However the focal point of the tax row is likely to come on Monday when Truss makes her own speech to a fringe event, a year after the disastrous party conference when she was briefly prime minister.

;

;In yet another sign of the extent to which some Tory MPs are becoming emboldened in speaking out, Truss was to call for No 10 to “revive Conservative values” and cut corporation tax to 19%.

;

;She was also expected to demand planning rules be relaxed to boost housebuilding and for fracking to restart, neither of which is government policy.

;

;Labour accused Truss of reviving the same fantasy economics that crashed the economy just 12 months ago”, and called for Sunak to repudiate her ideas.

;

;Interviewed on BBC One's Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg, the prime minister refused to commit to tax cuts, arguing: “The best tax cut we can give working people is to halve inflation.”

;

;During a sometimes tetchy performance, Sunak argued he was relaxed about taking office without an election and then dropping large parts of the Tories' 2019 manifesto because he instinctively understood what the public wanted.

;

;“I have a good sense of what the British people's priorities are,” he said. “I'm going to set about delivering for them. And that's the change that I'm going to bring.”

;

;The conference has already seen policy challenges from the right of the party, at times mixed with open jockeying for position by ministers trying to position themselves as a successor to Sunak should the Conservatives lose the election.

;

;Before the conference, Kemi Badenoch, the business secretary, and Suella Braverman, the home secretary, used newspaper interviews to reiterate their calls for the UK to leave the European convention on human rights (ECHR) – once again something that is not government policy.

;

;The New Conservatives, a culture war-friendly collection of right-leaning backbenchers, released polling on Sunday showing, they said, that a majority of voters and an overwhelming proportion of Tory voters support leaving the ECHR.

;

;On Monday, the group will hold a rally, pressing Sunak to adopt five manifesto pledges, covering ECHR withdrawal as well as tax cuts, massive cuts to immigration, a reduction in the numbers of young people attending university and a ban on “gender ideology in schools”.

;

;In a sign of how US-type culture war issues have become increasingly mainstream within the Conservatives, one of the co-founders of the New Conservatives, Tory backbencher Miriam Cates, used a fringe event on Sunday to argue without any evidence that internet pornography was a driving factor in people becoming transgender.

;

;“This is anecdotal, but you see an awful lot of trans women, so men, saying it was trans porn that led them into the trans arena,” she said. “So I have no doubt that this kind of extreme, violent and very disturbing pornographic material on the internet has got a lot to do with it.”

;

;The mass of MPs and even ministers pushing their own agendas has prompted concern in government about a potential for indisciplined and slapdash messaging going into a general election.

;

;While insisting he did personally not think that ill-discipline was yet a problem in the party, Andrew Mitchell, the international development minister, warned against “people sort of preening themselves on stage, showing off their colourful feathers”.

;

;He said: “As you're about to go into battle you don't start arguing the toss with the commanding officer. You get on with preparing to win that battle.

;

;“I don't think that the Tory party in the country or in parliament would tolerate that sort of self-indulgence at a time we need for our country and our party to win the next election.”
